revision.text:
Jennifer Latheef (born Month Day, Year) is a 32 year old vocal, daughter of Mohamed Latheef, a leading Maldivian politician and government critic in exile. She is also a strong member of the opposition.
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on 18 October, convicted of "terrorism" for joining a protest in September 2003 against deaths in prison and political repression.
She is being detained in Maafushi Prison on an island 18 miles south of the capital, Malé. Jennifer Latheef is reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her blood sugar.

'''Jennifer Latheef''' is a 32 year old [[Maldives|Maldivian]] [[journalist]] and [[photographer]] working for the daily [[Minivan News]]. She is the daughter of [[Mohamed Latheef]], a leading [[Maldives|Maldivian]] politician and government critic in [[exile]]. She is also a strong member of the opposition.
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on 18 October, convicted of "[[terrorism]]" for joining a protest in September [[2003]] against deaths in prison and political repression. [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513]
She is being detained in Maafushi Prison on the [[Maafushi Atoll]], 18 miles south of the capital, [[Malé]]. Jennifer Latheef is reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her [[glycemia|blood sugar]].

==References== *[http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/73739 Latheef under house arrest] - [[IFEX]] *[http://www.article19.org/pdfs/publications/maldives-press-freedom-mission-report.pdf Report by International Press Freedom and Freedom of Expression Mission to the Maldives]
[[Category:Living people|Latheef, Jennifer]] [[Category:Maldivian people|Latheef, Jennifer]] [[Category:Political prisoners|Latheef, Jennifer]]

'''Jennifer Latheef''' is a 32-year-old [[Maldives|Maldivian]] [[journalist]] and [[photographer]] working for the daily [[Minivan News]]. She is the daughter of [[Mohamed Latheef]], a leading [[Maldives|Maldivian]] politician and government critic in [[exile]]. According to an [[Amnesty International]] report, released in 2003, Jennifer Latheef
is an artist and video film producer particularly focusing on the prevalence of sexual abuse in the country. She is known for holding views critical of the government and against censorship, and this is believed to be the main reason for her continued detention. She is currently detained under house arrest in Malé. In addition, it is believed that Jennifer Latheef’s continued detention may be a measure by the government to limit the activities of her father, Mohamed Latheef, a Maldivian politician currently living in exile in Sri Lanka where he is engaged in a campaign of peaceful political opposition to the Government of Maldives.Amnesty International, [http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA290052003 The Republic of Maldives: Prisoners of conscience should be released], 19 November 2003
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on [[October 18]], [[2005]], convicted of "[[terrorism]]" for joining a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|protest]] in September [[2003]] against deaths in prison and political repression.Reporters sans frontières, [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513 Jennifer Latheef - In prison since 18 October 2005] Amnesty International adopted her as a Prisoner of Conscience during her time in prison and campaigned for her release. Minivan News, [http://minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1333 Jennifer Latheef Declared Amnesty International Prisoner of Conscience], 18 October 2005 She was detained in Maafushi Prison on the [[Kaafu Atoll]], 18 miles south of the capital, [[Malé]]. She was reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her [[glycemia|blood sugar]]. {{citeneeded}} She was released on 16 August 2006. She was informed of her release from house arrest through a presidential pardon. Initially, she refused to accept the government offer of release on two grounds: firstly, that her release should have been unconditional and not through a pardon, since this would imply that she had committed a recognizably criminal offence – which she had not; and secondly, she insisted that the other four political prisoners convicted at the same trial should also be released. After consulting with friends and other human rights defenders, Jennifer Latheef agreed to accept the offer of release from house arrest. amnesty international in asia and the pacific, [http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/aproweb.nsf/pages/goodNews_maldives_ua27305 Good News from Maldives! Jennifer Latheef Freed], 26 October 2006 ==References== ==See also== *[[IFEX]] - [http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/73739 Latheef under house arrest] *[[ARTICLE 19]] - [http://www.article19.org/pdfs/publications/maldives-press-freedom-mission-report.pdf Report by International Press Freedom and Freedom of Expression Mission to the Maldives] [[Category:Living people|Latheef, Jennifer]] [[Category:Maldivian people|Latheef, Jennifer]] [[Category:Political prisoners|Latheef, Jennifer]]

'''Jennifer Latheef''' is a 32-year-old [[Maldives|Maldivian]] [[journalist]] and [[photographer]] working for the daily [[Minivan News]]. She is the daughter of [[Mohamed Latheef]], a leading [[Maldives|Maldivian]] politician and government critic in [[exile]]. According to an [[Amnesty International]] report released in 2003, Jennifer Latheef
is an artist and video film producer particularly focusing on the prevalence of sexual abuse in the country. However, people in the Maldives, including hardcore supporters of the Maldivian Democratic Party to which Jennifer and her father Mohamed Latheef belongs, are not aware of Jennifer's human rights activism nor an interest Jennifer has in promoting human rights. And as for her work as a journalist, it was only while she was in prison, that an article supposed to be written by Jennifer was published. It appeared in Minivan Daily, a paper promoting MDP edited by Aiminathu Najeeb, who happens to be Jennifer Latheef's aunt. Amnesty says she is known for holding views critical of the government and against censorship, and this is believed to be the main reason for her continued detention. She is currently detained under house arrest in Malé. In addition, it is believed that Jennifer Latheef’s continued detention may be a measure by the government to limit the activities of her father, Mohamed Latheef, a Maldivian politician currently living in exile in Sri Lanka where he is engaged in a campaign of peaceful political opposition to the Government of Maldives.Amnesty International, [http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA290052003 The Republic of Maldives: Prisoners of conscience should be released], 19 November 2003
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on [[October 18]], [[2005]], convicted of "[[terrorism]]" for joining a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|protest]] in September [[2003]] against deaths in prison and political repression.Reporters sans frontières, [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513 Jennifer Latheef - In prison since 18 October 2005] Amnesty International adopted her as a Prisoner of Conscience during her time in prison and campaigned for her release. Minivan News, [http://minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1333 Jennifer Latheef Declared Amnesty International Prisoner of Conscience], 18 October 2005 She was detained in Maafushi Prison on the [[Kaafu Atoll]], 18 miles south of the capital, [[Malé]]. She was reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her [[glycemia|blood sugar]]. {{citeneeded}} She was released on 16 August 2006. She was informed of her release from house arrest through a presidential pardon. Initially, she refused to accept the government offer of release on two grounds: firstly, that her release should have been unconditional and not through a pardon, since this would imply that she had committed a recognizably criminal offence – which she had not; and secondly, she insisted that the other four political prisoners convicted at the same trial should also be released. After consulting with friends and other human rights defenders, Jennifer Latheef agreed to accept the offer of release from house arrest. amnesty international in asia and the pacific, Jennifer Latheef's story is worth a read. It is the greatest hoax of the Maldives' democratic movement. A creation that has hoodwinked international NGOs like Amnesty International and Reporters sans frontières, to the extent that the credibility of these international organisations are in question. [http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/aproweb.nsf/pages/goodNews_maldives_ua27305 Good News from Maldives! Jennifer Latheef Freed], 26 October 2006 ==References== ==See also== *[[IFEX]] - [http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/73739 Latheef under house arrest] *[[ARTICLE 19]] - [http://www.article19.org/pdfs/publications/maldives-press-freedom-mission-report.pdf Report by International Press Freedom and Freedom of Expression Mission to the Maldives] [[Category:Living people|Latheef, Jennifer]] [[Category:Maldivian people|Latheef, Jennifer]]

She is the daughter of [[Mohamed Latheef]], a leading [[Maldives|Maldivian]] politician and government critic in [[exile]]. is an artist and video film producer particularly focusing on the prevalence of sexual abuse in the country. She is currently detained under house arrest in Malé. In addition, it is believed that Jennifer Latheef’s continued detention may be a measure by the government to limit the activities of her father, Mohamed Latheef, a Maldivian politician currently living in exile in Sri Lanka where he is engaged in a campaign of peaceful political opposition to the Government of Maldives.Amnesty International, [http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA290052003 The Republic of Maldives: Prisoners of conscience should be released], 19 November 2003
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on [[October 18]], [[2005]], convicted of "[[terrorism]]" for joining a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|protest]] in September [[2003]] against deaths in prison and political repression.Reporters sans frontières, [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513 Jennifer Latheef - In prison since 18 October 2005] Amnesty International adopted her as a Prisoner of Conscience during her time in prison and campaigned for her release. Minivan News, [http://minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1333 Jennifer Latheef Declared Amnesty International Prisoner of Conscience], 18 October 2005 She was detained in Maafushi Prison on the [[Kaafu Atoll]], 18 miles south of the capital, [[Malé]]. She was reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her [[glycemia|blood sugar]]. {{citeneeded}} She was released on 16 August 2006. She was informed of her release from house arrest through a presidential pardon. Initially, she refused to accept the government offer of release on two grounds: firstly, that her release should have been unconditional and not through a pardon, since this would imply that she had committed a recognizably criminal offence – which she had not; and secondly, she insisted that the other four political prisoners convicted at the same trial should also be released. revision.text:
'''Jennifer Latheef''' (born 1973) is a daughter of [[Mohamed Latheef]], a leading [[Maldives|Maldivian]] politician and government critic. She also worked as a [[Maldives|Maldivian]] [[journalist]] and [[photographer]] for a short period of time. According to an [[Amnesty International]] report released in 2003, Jennifer Latheef
is an artist and video film producer particularly focusing on the prevalence of sexual abuse in the country. She is known for holding views critical of the government and against censorship, and this is believed to be the main reason for her continued detention. She is currently detained under house arrest in Malé. In addition, it is believed that Jennifer Latheef’s continued detention may be a measure by the government to limit the activities of her father, Mohamed Latheef, a Maldivian politician currently living in exile in Sri Lanka where he is engaged in a campaign of peaceful political opposition to the Government of Maldives.Amnesty International, [http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA290052003 The Republic of Maldives: Prisoners of conscience should be released] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115181550/http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA290052003 |date=2006-11-15 }}, 19 November 2003
Jennifer Latheef was sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment on October 18, 2005, convicted of "[[terrorism]]" for joining a [[2003 Maldives civil unrest|protest]] in September 2003 against deaths in prison and political repression.Reporters sans frontières, [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513 Jennifer Latheef - In prison since 18 October 2005] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001232805/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=15513 |date=1 October 2006 }} Amnesty International adopted her as a Prisoner of Conscience during her time in prison and campaigned for her release. Minivan News, [http://minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1333 Jennifer Latheef Declared Amnesty International Prisoner of Conscience] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022062910/http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=1333 |date=2006-10-22 }}, 18 October 2005 She was detained in [[Maafushi Prison]] on the [[Kaafu Atoll]], 18 miles south of the capital, [[Malé]]. She was reportedly not being given regular access to the medication which she needs to take daily to regulate her [[blood sugar]]. {{Fact|date=February 2007}} She was released on August 16, 2006. She was informed of her release from house arrest through a presidential pardon. Initially, she refused to accept the government offer of release on two grounds: firstly, that her release should have been unconditional and not through a pardon, since this would imply that she had committed a recognizably criminal offence – which she had not; and secondly, she insisted that the other four political prisoners convicted at the same trial should also be released. After consulting with friends and other [[human rights defender]]s, Jennifer Latheef agreed to accept the offer of release from house arrest. amnesty international in asia and the pacific, [http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/aproweb.nsf/pages/goodNews_maldives_ua27305 Good News from Maldives! Jennifer Latheef Freed] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109042134/http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/apro/aproweb.nsf/pages/goodNews_maldives_ua27305 |date=2006-11-09 }}, 26 October 2006 ==See also== *[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange|IFEX]] - [http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/73739 Latheef under house arrest] *[[ARTICLE 19]] - [http://www.article19.org/pdfs/publications/maldives-press-freedom-mission-report.pdf Report by International Press Freedom and Freedom of Expression Mission to the Maldives] *[[Minivan News]] - [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928035806/http://www.minivannews.com/news/news.php?id=2673 Jennifer Latheef Resigns From MDP] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Latheef, Jennifer}} [[Category:Amnesty International prisoners of conscience held by the Maldives]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maldivian activists]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[Category:Maldivian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:People imprisoned on charges of terrorism]] [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:20th-century Maldivian writers]] [[Category:21st-century Maldivian writers]]
